Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding the thermodynamics of crystalline materials using advanced molecular simulation sampling methods

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351635
Shirts

The theory of solid phase materials has focused to a large extent on zero temperature crystal minima and harmonic approximations around these minima. In realistic systems, such as crystals of pharmaceutical agents or metal oxides for functional materials, the room temperature or high temperature properties are of most interest. This means free energy minima and thermodynamic ensembles are the important quantities, rather than potential energy minima and fixed structures. Little previous research has examined the free energy landscape of solids more complex than Lennard-Jones spheres or atomic salts. This proposal brings together methods for simulating multiple thermodynamic ensembles in new ways in order to achieve the necessary levels of sampling required for realistic crystal systems. The proposed methods will scale in a straightforward way to multicomponent crystals and to potential functions of increasing accuracy.

A better understanding of the thermodynamics of molecular crystals and an improved ability to quantitatively predict their properties is vital for continued improvement of the pharmaceutical development pipeline, allowing drugs to be formulated and processed more safely, easily and cheaply. The methods developed here will also be useful for predictive tools for processing of a broad range of crystalline materials including pigments, pesticides and other agrochemicals, food additives, electronic materials, ceramics and explosives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many molecules of commercial importance, such as drugs, pigments, pesticides, electronic materials, ceramics and explosives are produced, stored and used as crystals. However, most molecules can form multiple crystal arrangements, called polymorphs, each of which can have different properties. These include vital properties for the molecule to function, such as stability for explosives, bioavailability for drugs, or electrical conductivity for electronic crystals. It is currently impossible to know before a molecule is manufactured which stable forms may form, or if alternate forms exist that have not yet been encountered. 

 

Researchers have started to use computational models to try to predict what crystal polymorphs new molecules can take, and which ones of these polymorphs will be most stable. These approaches have had some limited success for very simple molecules. But the existing approaches have focused to a large extent on zero-temperature approaches, which model the crystal as only the lowest energy single structure, and simply attempt to find this lowest energy structure. Occasionally, the fluctuations of the molecule around this lowest energy well are considered as well.

 

In this project, we have investigated to what extent predictions of stability change when including realistic amounts of molecular motion. We have found that for small, rigid molecules the approaches that include small molecular fluctuations work well, but for the types of molecules used in most applications, which are larger and more flexible, the simple approximations do not provide experimental levels of accuracy.

 

During this project, we have developed new methods for adding more realistic approaches to the currently-used simple ways to estimate stability, such as allowing the molecule to expand unevenly in each direction. We have shown that even these extensions do not help much; the full fluctuations of molecular motion must be used.

 

What we have instead found in our research is that rather than just fluctuating around one structure, most molecules vibrate around several, or even many different structures, and the fluctuations around each have different strengths and sizes. Additionally, many of the single structure techniques consider just a few molecules at a time. When more molecules are considered packed together, there are additional collective movements that only happen with these larger, more realistic sets of molecules. Finally, most molecules are sufficiently flexible that they can pack together in several different arrangements that rapidly interconvert back and forth. We have found that the contribution of molecular fluctuation to the properties may be relatively accurate even if the model of the molecule itself is relatively simple, suggesting that future predictions may be able to use a highly accurate model for the energy, and a cheaper model to compute the more expensive contribution of fluctuations.

 

We have developed workflows for these full-fluctuation molecular dynamics approaches that, although expensive, are of reasonable cost given the increasing power of available computational power today. These approaches include better methods for calculating the contribution of small molecular fluctuations to stability, workflows for calculating the stability of complex molecules as a function of temperature, and workflows for calculating the stability of polymorphs as a function of temperature and pressure. Some of these approaches are even now being used by companies to estimate the amount of fluctuations and the relative stability of pharmaceuticals in production.  

 

As part of the integrated education and research part of this grant, I have developed a new course on research statistics and data analysis, helped start an undergraduate group aiding engineering and science students to get involved in public policy. I have also helped found the new open access journal "The Living Journal of Computational Molecular Science" (LiveCoMS), which provides a peer-reviewed home for manuscripts which share best practices in molecular modeling and simulation, in particular “living documents” than can be regularly updated with community input, such as perpetually updated reviews, high-quality tutorials, comparisons between software packages, and other documents which can help researchers improve the quality of the their work.
